problem_text: A subgroup H of a group G is called pronormal if H and Hg are conjugate in ⟨H, Hg⟩ for every g ∈ G. A subgroup H of a group G is called abnormal if g ∈ ⟨H, Hg⟩ for every g ∈ G. Does there exist an infinite group that does not contain nontrivial proper pronormal subgroups? The question is equivalent to the following: does there exist an infinite simple group that does not contain proper abnormal subgroups? D. O. Revin
answer: Yes, it does (S. Corson, Monatsh. Math. (2025) https://doi.org/10.1007/s00605-025-02116-8.
